policies.general:
702 E. Broadway St., Eden, TX, 76837

All incoming mail is subject to screening. Detained individuals may send mail from the facility and purchase stamps for use. There is generally no limit to the amount of correspondence detained individuals may send at their own expense. Detained individuals without any funds or external support will be provided stamps at government expense.

Letters sent must include the following information:

Full name

Alien number

Housing Location

PO Box 1617 Eden, Texas 76837
policies.digital:
Detained individuals cannot receive any incoming calls.

To get in touch with a detained individual to leave an urgent message, call (325)-869-7204 ext. 62260 and leave the detained individual's full name, alien registration number, and the telephone number where you can be reached. Messages will be forwarded to the detained individual.
policies.commissary:

Core Civic Inmate Trust

First Name and Last Name, Commissary Number

Facility-EDC

P.O. Box 933488

Atlanta, GA 31193-3488

Do not send cash—it will be returned to the sender.
policies.visitation:
Friends and Family Visits

Visits are non-contact. Under no circumstances may visitors give property or money to detained individuals. Only 4 visitors allowed per visitation. All visitors are subject to search—search procedures include pat-downs, inspection of belongings, and a metal scan search.

Visitors must present a valid and verifiable government-issued ID card to center the facility (drivers license, passport, etc.) Children under 16 are required to have a birth certificate presented at the time of visit. Minors must always be accompanied by an adult guardian.

resources.legal: There is a list of attorneys and pro bono agencies that work in Louisiana on https://laaid.org
resources.visitation:
LaAID has volunteers in the areas of the State near detention centers. Will help released individuals by transportation, assistance at the airport, meals, access to a phone to contact family, items they may need for travel. Can write letters to people in detention, advocate for medical assistance and contact the ombudsman office for civil rights violations. Can transport people released on bond if provided enough time to drive the hour to the facility prior to the individual's release. https://laaid.org

We maintain a text phone line for released individuals' families to contact us. 318-769-0852

Home is Here offers sponsorship by community groups in Louisiana. This includes submitting sponsorship release requests for those detained without sponsors, placement with hosts in their homes and an address for release, along with other resettlement support for short, medium, and long-term periods depending on capacity.

www.homeisherenola.org

info@homeisherenola.org

1610 Oretha Castle Haley Blvd. Suite A New Orleans, LA 70119

Ask for a sponsorship referral through FFI National Detention Hotline: 9233# (free from inside detention) or 209-757-3733.
resources.prSupport: We can host overnight when needed, provide a meal or snack, pickup from detention center when an individual is paying bond. ICE will bus non-bond individuals to nearest airport (Alexandria, LA, Lafayette, LA, Baton Rouge, LA, Jackson, MS). We assist at Lafayette airport to help them get boarding passes and through security and will take an individual to the Lafayette Greyhound bus station if needed or host for the night if there is a delay in their travel. Individuals from Jackson, Winn, occasionally Adams and LaSalle are bused to Shreveport Church of the Highlands, where they can get a meal, stay the night, be transported to the bus, airport, or train for travel that day or the next day. We can also apply for Miles4Migrants plane tickets for those who are indigent. .

General Guidelines

Letters must include the housing unit/dorm/bunk number.

Examples:

W5-A-101-7L (West Facility, Unit 5, Dorm A , Cell 101, Bunk 7-Lower level)

E3-B-10U

(East Facility, Unit 3, Dorm B, Bunk 10-Upper Level)

No care packages are accepted. Items of utter necessity will be accepted with deportation officer pre-approval.

Books must have deportation officer pre-approval (obtained by the individual via a KITE that specifies title and author). Books must be softcover and shipped to the immigrant directly from a publisher or distributor.

Travel packages: When a Travel Notice has been issued, a travel package will be accepted. Immigrants being deported may take a carry-on. Can supplement or replace items they were detained with, but do not send cell phones or other electronics.

*At present, packages cannot be hand delivered and must be shipped via USPS, Fed. Ex., or UPS.
policies.digital:
Phone company:

GettingOut

It is recommended that you do not deposit funds directly into phone/video accounts as individuals are unable to withdraw the balance in their accounts upon release. Deposit funds in their commissary accounts and individuals can transfer funds into their telephone/video account as needed.
policies.commissary:
Commissary company: www.accesscorrections.com

Funds can be deposited into the commissary account online, through kiosks, and by sending the detained individual a Western Union or USPS money order made out to his/her name. (Cash will be accepted but there is risk and is not recommended.)
policies.visitation:
1. At present, all social visits are non-contact (ie: plexiglass dividers and phones).

2. Social visits are 1-hour long and must occur on the assigned days and times (2-days/week , 4-hour/day) unless otherwise approved by a deportation officer.

3. Visitation assignments are dorm-based. Verify visitation schedule prior to your visit by contacting the individual and the facility ahead of time.

Texas RioGrande Legal Aid provides help with Adjustment of Status, Asylum applications, Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA), Naturalization/Citizenship, Removal hearings, Special Immigrant Juvenile Status, T visas, U visas, Violence Against Women Act (VAWA) petitions, Help completing forms, Filings with USCIS, Representation at Asylum Interviews (Credible Fear Interviews, Reasonable Fear Interviews), Representation before the Immigration Court, Representation before the Board of Immigration Appeals (BIA), Federal court appeals

Services in English and Spanish

Phone:

Toll-free:

800-369-9270

Fax:

(512) 447-3940
resources.visitation:
Legal representatives may request video teleconference (VTC) meetings via Zoom or confidential legal phone calls with their clients or prospective clients by email at cbintake@geogroup.com. A Coastal Bend staff member will email back with a confirmed date and time. Legal representatives may also schedule VTC meetings or calls by dialing (361) 767-3400.

The same guidelines for in-person attorney/client visits will apply to VTC meetings and legal calls. Only legal representatives, legal assistants, and interpreters will be allowed; no family or friends of the clients are permitted. The attorney and/or his/her agents may contact outside interpretation services during the call or session. The sessions will be confidential; a visitation officer will be stationed outside of the confidential room to ensure security by standing out of earshot but within eyeshot.

On Saturdays, men can receive visits from 8 a.m. to 9:45 a.m. and 2 p.m. to 3:45 p.m.

On Sundays, men can receive visits from 8 a.m. to 9:45 a.m.

On Sundays, women can receive visits from 2 p.m. to 3:45 p.m.

Individuals are allotted one session (45 minutes) for visits on their assigned weekend. A maximum of two visitors are allowed per individual, including minor children.

To ensure adequate time to process visitors through security, all visitors must arrive 1 hour prior to the scheduled visit time.

Holiday Visitation: Visiting will be held for specific federal holidays. Visitation on holidays will be 8 a.m. to 9:45 a.m. and 2 p.m. to 3:45 p.m. for both men and women and will be on a first come first serve basis.

resources.legal: There is a list of attorneys and pro bono agencies that work in Louisiana on our website https://laaid.org
resources.visitation:
LaAID has volunteers in the areas of the State near detention centers. We will help released individuals by transportation when needed, assistance at the airport, meals, access to a phone to contact family, other items that they may need for travel. We can write letters to persons in detention, advocate for medical assistance and contact the ombudsman office for civil rights violations. We can transport people released on bond if provided enough time to drive the hour to the facility prior to the individual's release. https://laaid.org We maintain a text phone line for released individual’s families to contact us. 318-769-0852

Home is Here offers sponsorship by community groups in Louisiana. This includes submitting sponsorship release requests for those detained without sponsors, placement with hosts in their homes and an address for release, along with other resettlement support for short, medium, and long-term periods depending on capacity.

www.homeisherenola.org

info@homeisherenola.org

1610 Oretha Castle Haley Blvd. Suite A New Orleans, LA 70119

Ask for a sponsorship referral through FFI National Detention Hotline: 9233# (free from inside detention) or 209-757-3733.
resources.prSupport: We can host overnight when needed, provide a meal or snack, pickup from detention center when an individual is paying bond. ICE will bus non-bond individuals to nearest airport (Alexandria, LA, Lafayette, LA, Baton Rouge, LA, Jackson, MS). We assist at Lafayette airport to help them get boarding passes and through security and will take an individual to the Lafayette Greyhound bus station if needed or host for the night if there is a delay in their travel. Individuals from Jackson, Winn, occasionally Adams and LaSalle are bused to Shreveport Church of the Highlands, where they can get a meal, stay the night, be transported to the bus, airport, or train for travel that day or the next day. We can also apply for Miles4Migrants plane tickets for those who are indigent.

policies.digital: Detained individuals cannot receive incoming calls. If you need to get in touch with a detained individual to leave an urgent message, you must call (940) 864-6200 and leave the detained individual's full name, alien registration number and your name and telephone number where you can be reached. The detained individual will be given your message.
policies.commissary: Bonds for aliens detained by ICE may be posted at ICE ERO bond acceptance offices nationwide, Monday through Friday (except public holidays) between the hours of 9 a.m. and 3 p.m., local time. For a list of ICE ERO bond acceptance offices nearest you or for bond information, click here. You must have the last name of the detained individual and alien registration number before calling. Acceptable forms of payment to post a bond are money orders, cashier’s checks or certified checks. For all bonds $10,000 and over, the only accepted method of payment is a single cashier or certified check. Payments must be made payable to “U.S. Department of Homeland Security” or “Immigration and Customs Enforcement.”

resources.visitation: Mariposas Sin Fronteras is a Tucson, AZ based group that seeks to end the systemic violence and abuse of LGBTQ people held in prison and immigration detention. They envision a society that no longer finds solutions in the system of immigration detention or the prison industrial complex. As they work toward that goal, they support LGBTQ people currently detained in Eloy and Florence Detention Centers through visits, letters, bond support, advocacy, and housing upon freedom from detention.

TELEPHONE & COMMISSARY FUNDS

Advance Pay Phone – this option allows the resident to call only your phone number with the money you load. You can load money the following ways:

PIN Debit – this option allows resident to call any phone number with the money you load. You can load the money the following way:

-add the resident to your account (you will need the resident's ID number)

-add your payment details

-load money on the PIN Debit option

Phone Card/Commissary -This option allows the resident to purchase a calling card from Commissary (in $20 amounts) and call any phone number with it. You can load the money the following ways:

2. Touchpayonline.com (you will need the resident's ID number and site ID (220)

-create your account

-add the resident to your account

-add your payment details

-load money on the resident's Commissary Account

policies.commissary:
There are four ways to deposit money:

1. Online

Visit the access websiteto create an account and deposit money on behalf of an individual. There is a fee for online deposits. Deposits are credited to the individual's account within minutes.

2. Telephone

Call Access Corrections at 866-345-1884 to create an account and deposit money on behalf of an individual. There is a fee for telephone deposits. Deposits are credited to the individual's account within minutes.

3. In Person at Lobby & 4. Video Visitation Kiosks

Deposits are accepted at kiosks located in the Jail Lobby or Video Visitation. The kiosk is provided for cash and credit card deposits only. There is a fee for deposits made on the kiosks.

resources.legal: Meg Moran, NH Legal Assistance, mmoran@nhla.org
resources.visitation:
NH Immigrant Visitation Program (NHIVP) - a collaboration between the American Friends Service Committee and the NH Conference of the United Church of Christ.

They conduct weekly visits (Wednesdays, 9 AM to 12 noon) to the Strafford County jail to provide emotional/spiritual support and KYR. NHIVP collaborates with several partners, including faith-based groups, to address needs for funds for telephone/commissary, bonds, and legal representation, as well as host homes and other forms of post-detention support.
resources.organizing: Advocacy related to conditions issues is an underdeveloped area in NH. ACLU-NH filed a class action lawsuit (ongoing) to win the release of medically vulnerable individuals during the early months of COVID-19.
resources.prSupport: Statewide, there are 7-8 host home/hospitality accompaniment networks which provide a variety of post-detention support including housing, transportation and financial assistance.

9:00 A.M. to 11:40 A.M. — All Housing Areas

3:00 P.M. to 3:40 P.M. — All Housing Areas

8:00 P.M. to 10:00 P.M. — All Housing Areas (dependent on housing location)

Visitation will be granted on a first come, first served basis, and each visit is 20 minutes in length. Each individual can receive a maximum of two (2), 20-minute visits per week. Individuals on certain types of disciplinary restriction may not be permitted visitors. Visitors may only visit one (1) individual per day.

resources.legal: There is a list of attorneys and pro bono agencies that work in Louisiana on https://laaid.org
resources.visitation:
LaAID has volunteers in the areas of the State near detention centers. Will help released individuals by transportation, assistance at the airport, meals, access to a phone to contact family, items they may need for travel. Can write letters to people in detention, advocate for medical assistance and contact the ombudsman office for civil rights violations. Can transport people released on bond if provided enough time to drive the hour to the facility prior to the individual's release. https://laaid.org

We maintain a text phone line for released individuals' families to contact us. 318-769-0852

Home is Here offers sponsorship by community groups in Louisiana. This includes submitting sponsorship release requests for those detained without sponsors, placement with hosts in their homes and an address for release, along with other resettlement support for short, medium, and long-term periods depending on capacity.

www.homeisherenola.org

info@homeisherenola.org

1610 Oretha Castle Haley Blvd. Suite A New Orleans, LA 70119

Ask for a sponsorship referral through FFI National Detention Hotline: 9233# (free from inside detention) or 209-757-3733.
resources.prSupport: We can host overnight when needed, provide a meal or snack, pickup from detention center when an individual is paying bond. ICE will bus non-bond individuals to nearest airport (Alexandria, LA, Lafayette, LA, Baton Rouge, LA, Jackson, MS). We assist at Lafayette airport to help them get boarding passes and through security and will take an individual to the Lafayette Greyhound bus station if needed or host for the night if there is a delay in their travel. Individuals from Jackson, Winn, occasionally Adams and LaSalle are bused to Shreveport Church of the Highlands, where they can get a meal, stay the night, be transported to the bus, airport, or train for travel that day or the next day. We can also apply for Miles4Migrants plane tickets for those who are indigent.

policies.visitation: Saturdays and Sundays, 11am -5pm. No appointment necessary. Cell phones are not permitted, but you may carry in paper and pen (you just can’t give it to the individual).

1. Obtain money orders and / or cashier’s checks made payable to the individual. Personal

checks and cash are not accepted.

2. Mail money orders and / or cashier’s checks in envelopes addressed in the following manner:

CCA Detainee Trust

(Individual Last Name, Individual First Name / Individual CCA Commissary #)

Facility: ADAMS

P.O. Box 933488

Atlanta, GA 31193-3488

3. Make sure the sender's first and last name and return address is on the envelope.

4. Do NOT include any correspondence such as letters, cards, pictures, or packages with a money order or cashier’s check. None of these items sent to this address will be forwarded to the individual or returned to sender.

Western Union Instructions

resources.legal: There is a list of attorneys and pro bono agencies that work in Louisiana on our website https://laaid.org
resources.visitation:
LaAID has volunteers in the areas of the State near detention centers. We will help released individuals by transportation when needed, assistance at the airport, meals, access to a phone to contact family, other items that they may need for travel. We can write letters to persons in detention, advocate for medical assistance and contact the ombudsman office for civil rights violations. We can transport people released on bond if provided enough time to drive the hour to the facility prior to the individual's release. https://laaid.org We maintain a text phone line for released individual’s families to contact us. 318-769-0852

Home is Here offers sponsorship by community groups in Louisiana. This includes submitting sponsorship release requests for those detained without sponsors, placement with hosts in their homes and an address for release, along with other resettlement support for short, medium, and long-term periods depending on capacity.

info@homeisherenola.org

resources.prSupport: We can host overnight when needed, provide a meal or snack, pickup from detention center when an individual is paying bond. ICE will bus non-bond individuals to nearest airport (Alexandria, LA, Lafayette, LA, Baton Rouge, LA, Jackson, MS). We assist at Lafayette airport to help them get boarding passes and through security and will take an individual to the Lafayette Greyhound bus station if needed or host for the night if there is a delay in their travel. Individuals from Jackson, Winn, occasionally Adams and LaSalle are bused to Shreveport Church of the Highlands, where they can get a meal, stay the night, be transported to the bus, airport, or train for travel that day or the next day. We can also apply for Miles4Migrants plane tickets for those who are indigent. .

No care packages are accepted. Items of utter necessity will be accepted with deportation officer pre-approval. Books must have deportation officer pre-approval (obtained by the individual via a KITE that specifies title and author).
